awd_titl_txt: Regulation of Cell Adhesions by Mechanical Force
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to understanding how biological materials respond to mechanical force. Adhesion receptors are proteins in the plasma membrane that mediate cell binding to other cells or to the extracellular matrix.  These receptors sense and transmit forces between cells and the external environment.  Specifically, integrins transmit mechanical and biochemical information.  This information critically guides life processes such as embryonic development, and also plays a role in diseases such as cancer, hypertension, osteoporosis and atherosclerosis. Integrins undergo drastic, long-range changes in response to biochemical signals or mechanical stresses. Exactly how integrin amino acid residues rearrange in response to force is largely unknown due to the technical challenges in observing shifts in residue positions and interactions at the single protein level.  This hampers our ability to understand or modulate these processes that can lead to disease. This research will employ cell biology, computational simulations, biophysics, chemistry and material science approaches to elucidate the detailed pathways of force-dependent changes in integrins conformation and their roles in cell regulation.

The overarching objective of this research is to understand, at near-atomic level, how integrin conformation is modulated by mechanical force and how the resultant conformational transitions regulate cell behavior. The research team will develop new numerical tools to perform molecular dynamics simulations of integrins under force. These models will be used to predict mutations that stabilize or destabilize specific integrin states, which will then be tested experimentally for their effects on mechanosensing in live cells. By combining modeling with experiments, we will elucidate detailed pathways of force-dependent conformational transitions and their role in biology. This multidisciplinary approach will broaden the participation of diverse communities and underrepresented groups and positively impact engineering and material science education. Furthermore, this research may result in new approaches to design and produce biomimetic and smart materials for engineering applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has helped us better understand how cells work together to form our bodies. Central to this process are proteins called integrins, which span the cell membrane and link the inside of the cell to the external environment. Integrins bind to proteins of the extracellular matrix such as collagen, thereby forming the 3-dimensional structures of our tissues and organs. Once thought to be simple anchors that ‘integrate’ external and internal environments, integrins are now known to be dynamic and responsive to mechanical forces—changing shape under physical stress and regulating cell activity in a variety of conditions. These shape changes are crucial for how cells repair tissue, move through the body, and participate in complex processes like wound healing, blood clotting (hemostasis), and cancer progression. Our project revealed that two very closely related integrins that carry out many functions in an identical manner respond differently to mechanical forces. By combining lab experiments with computer simulations, we identified specific regions within these proteins, which are separate from those that respond to chemical signals like drug binding or ligand interactions, that are responsible for these differences. Using multiscale computational models, we tracked how integrins transition between "off" and "on" states through a series of intermediate shapes—brief but critical forms that aren’t fully active or inactive. These intermediate states play a key role in helping cells form strong, stable attachments to the extracellular matrix. Including these often-overlooked states in our simulations helped us more accurately explain how partially activated integrins support cell adhesion by increasing their binding strength. Another important finding was that the organization of integrins within cell adhesions is a crucial structural feature for cellular sensing of the external environment. It not only influences how cells sense stiffness in their environment but also how they recognize and bind specific ligands. Our model showed that both external and internal forces help stabilize these adhesions—and they can work independently. However, integrin-ligand bonds only become stronger up to a certain force threshold. Beyond that, the bonds break and the adhesion disassemble—unless it is reinforced by internal proteins.

In addition to the scientific discoveries, this project had a strong educational impact. It supported master’s and Ph.D. students, a postdoctoral researcher, and involved undergraduates in hands-on computational modeling. Their work led to conference presentations, including an award-winning poster, and contributed to a publication that received Best Paper recognition. The findings have been published in top scientific journals, and all simulation tools and data have been made publicly available. These insights could help drive the design of smart biomaterials that respond to mechanical forces, with potential applications in tissue engineering, wound healing, and cancer treatment. Elucidiating how integrins respond to physical stress bring us a step closer to therapies that can better replicate or guide the body’s natural processes.
